questions.title: Question 1 for Class 190927
questions.main: How does a steep (or strong) pressure gradient appear on a weather map?
questions.answer: A strong pressure gradient is represented as isobars close together.

questions.title: Question 2 for Class 190927
questions.main: If the outflow of air around a surface high pressure area is greater than the convergence of air aloft you would observe:
questions.answer: C) a decrease in the central pressure

mcq.option: A) an increase in pressure in the center of the high
B) movement of the high toward the northeast
C) a decrease in the central pressure

questions.title: Question 4 for Class 190927
questions.main: Which of the following is not a way of producing clouds?
questions.answer: E) air motions caused by subsidence

mcq.option: A) lifting air along a topographic barrier
B) lifting air along a front
C) warming the surface of the earth
E) air motions caused by subsidence

questions.title: Question 5 for Class 190927
questions.main: What are the necessary ingredients for a mid-latitude cyclonic storm to develop into a huge storm system?
questions.answer: Upper-level divergence (usually associated with a shortwave) surface convergence strong horizontal temperature contrast temperature advection.

questions.title: Question 6 for Class 190927
questions.main: Describe the conditions necessary to produce stratocumulus clouds by mixing.
questions.answer: The air must be stable and close to saturation.

questions.title: Question 7 for Class 190927
questions.main: Distinguish among a tropical depression a tropical storm and a hurricane.
questions.answer: Initially the mass of thunderstorms with only a slight wind circulation is known as a tropical disturbance or tropical wave. The tropical disturbance becomes a tropical depression when the winds increase to between 20 and 34 knots and several closed isobars appear about its center on a surface weather map. When the isobars are packed together and the winds are between 35 and 64 knots the tropical depression becomes a tropical storm. The tropical storm is classified as a hurricane only when its winds exceed 64 knots (74 miles/hour).
